author: InvestorForLife
body: Proud of you my friend. Does wonders to being more empathetic. It gave me a sixth sense and made me more cognizant emotions / feelings with my significant other.

author: Flying_madman
body: True. I haven't checked the spread on it, but I bet it's atrocious. I need to be more cognizant of that, got burned a few times lately by low liquidity plays even when I was bigly right.

author: wsbloverrrrrr
body:
Cognizant is an easy one bc it's a consultancy, as in they don't have a software to sell. Splunk focuses mostly on IT operations, whereas Palantir built a software platform that can handle any type of data-driven operations, hence allowing it to replicate Splunk, ERPs, supply chain operations, healthcare, etc. That said, there is some tradeoffs (larger learning curve than Splunk/others, steeper pricing, etc.).

The stock is definitely carrying a premium and by no means cheap at all, but I'm not worried about holding shares of a company with great outlook. And most of its peers (who have worse business/products) are at a higher valuation/premium. If anything, comments like these give me confidence that this stock will be a money maker as it means there is a huge knowledge gap between what the public thinks it does vs. what it actually does.

author: AlbumGuide
body: For sure bruh, just like ACN, CTSH, INFY..all of the great SaaS companies bruh.

author: Lund26
body: Well it depends how you look at it.  They could be cognizant of the potential of another short squeeze (as they said in their last earnings,) and want to make sure they get something out of it.  They could also be aware of the fact that the price may never reach those highs again and want to still make use of this elevated price.  Personally I believe in the former, but not to the extent of some others in this thread

author: Isthiswittyenough92
body: Appreciate the thought brother (or sister). In all fairness I say yolo in jest. I'm VERY cognizant of trading as a potential for risk and talked all about this GME win at treatment. I likely won't "YOLO" per se but I do appreciate good DD

author: NegativeTangibleBook
body:
As a lone trade, I would not trade. Integrated as part of my larger strategy, I’d consider various approaches, e.g. selling TLT puts to partially/fully fund purchases of HYG puts, being cognizant of both IV and HV and highly aware of  the carrying cost. *This is just a spitball trade idea and not something I’ve implemented.*

I look at data in a more simplistic way, I presume. Rather than understanding why we got here and what that means, I simply ask myself a few questions: 
- where are we?
- have we been here before?
- if yes, how often?
- what happened next?

Assuming all of the above is attractive (subjective) in my eyes, then the last questions involves how to/when to put on a trade and how to/when to take it off, assuming the possibilities exists.

This specific idea (it’s not a trade) is something I’ve been observing and shared.

author: xluik
body:
Just be cognizant that you're getting in the market at the all time high. So odds are against you at this stage of the market cycle. However, if you're in for the long run, I suggest reading this before beginning your journey and start a durable portfolio throughout your investing years ahead:

https://hiddenforces.io/wp-content/uploads/2020/02/Rundown-Ep.122-FINAL-The-Allegory-of-the-Hawk-and-Serpent-Chris-Cole-1.pdf

author: Georgex2inthejungle
body: I mean all shares with 0 hedge isnt “VERY cognizant” of risk but at least your not playing with any crazy amounts of delta... i guess

author: Legitimate-Space8847
body:
Boy oh boy ... that is more money than my savings. I can tell you one things and that is embrace your losses more than your victories. Losses will change way faster, make you more cognizant of your decisions. Victories are good but losses can be better, provided you see a silver lining.

Take some break, come back and start fresh. You lose only when you quit!

author: Tendie_rizer
body: Apes only know ASL so you have to be cognizant to that

author: ragnaroksunset
body: It's not necessarily bad, but you need to be far more cognizant of why you're going to cash.  Relying on rules of thumb, especially ones from a macroeconomic regime we are light years away from, carries its own risks.

author: Prestigious_Ear884
body: Meth-cognizant

author: sclongjohnson
body: They lobbied our congress out of automating our taxes years ago. Fuck Intuit and Fuck H&R Block

author: Im_Sorry_MissJackson
body: I’m sorry but are you saying Intuit, the software company that makes TurboTax, is responsible for our complicated tax code? They have nothing to do with tax laws. They provide a product that makes it very easy to file taxes for noobs and experienced people alike. Taxes have been complicated since our government has made it so complicated for the past multiple decades. It was complicated before TurboTax existed.

author: Thin-Course-4054
body: dude is a sales rep for intuit

author: ppp475
body: Intuit has (successfully) lobbied multiple times for increased complexity in the tax code. They didn't start it, but they definitely made it worse.

body: A lot of countries that still use cash have automatic taxes already. The reason the IS doesn’t is because of intuit and HR Block’s lobbying to keep it that way.

author: Im_Sorry_MissJackson
body: LOL I don’t care about intuit or TurboTax.. Just seems silly to me that people blame them for offering a product that makes filing taxes easier, it is a legit service that obviously a lot of ppl find valuable
